text: [Music]
this book was uh inspired you might say
by the recognition that we are coming up
in February 2009 to the bicentennial of
Lincoln's birth and there we can expect
even greater interest in Lincoln than
normal and perhaps hoopla there will be
a Steven Spielberg movie about Lincoln
I'm not one of those who tends to think
all that highly of Hollywood history uh
there's a lot of things coming out about
Lincoln which are I'd say from a
scholarly point of view not very
rigorous or valuable the point of this
book was to get some very distinguished
Scholars some of whom have never really
written about Lincoln before but are
Scholars on the 19th century to try to
put Lincoln into the context of his time
and in so doing to really get away from
what I think is a tendency now noways to
just study Lincoln people who study
Lincoln just look at Lincoln Lincoln's
psychology explains Lincoln's actions
Lincoln's career as a lawyer explains
the stance he took on slavery uh
Lincoln's uh you know experience with
his wife explain certain things he did
in other words to understand Lincoln you
only have to know Lincoln according to a
lot of literature that is out there now
and we don't really as historians we
don't really feel that is uh an adequate
way of looking at Lincoln Lincoln's a
man of his time Lincoln is influenced by
people in his time he his relationship
with abolitionists with
African-Americans with members of
Congress uh these are all affecting
Lincoln's views so you got to step out
from Lincoln to look at the broad
picture of 19th century America and
that's what we try to do uh in in this
book Lincoln is still Central but it's
Lincoln as a man of his era not just
Lincoln pulled out of context as some
kind of you know icon without history
I chose people for this book some of
whom as I say had never written about
Lincoln Shan Wen for example who's a
scholar at Princeton who wrote a very
fine book a couple years ago on the rise
of American democracy Lincoln comes in
at the end but he wrote an essay for
this about Lincoln and democracy uh you
can't understand that until you you know
you can't write about that unless you
think about the whole trend of
democratic expansion and Democratic
exclusion uh in the 19th century or
again James mcferson who has written a
lot of about the Civil War very very
fine scholar of the Civil War he wrote
about Lincoln and his role as
commander-in-chief of the army but again
what is you know and by the way of
course very relevant today what is the
role of the president in setting
military strategy in trying to you know
relate to members of the army the you
know leaders of the army does the
president just defer to them does he try
to give them strategic uh uh Insight Etc
my own essay is actually about Lincoln
and his plan which he held to for much
of his life to try to in the phrase of
the 19th century
colonize emancipated slaves that is send
them out of the country to somewhere
else for most of his life Lincoln could
not really think of this as a biracial
Society he thought of black people as
alien as somehow not really assimilable
he felt racism was deeply embedded in
American life he thought the best thing
for emancipated slaves would be to send
them somewhere else whether Africa
Central America where they can have
their own National identity and that's
not something most writers about Lincoln
emphasized but that was an important
feature of his outlook for a long long
time and again to understand that you
have to understand how widely shared
this view of colonizing blacks or
separating the races was in that period
